A BarITIn SNso REBntKED nY A BATnTIMOuE LADY.
A good anecdote is told of Mrs. Patterson of Bal­
timore, the lady connected with the Bonaparte
family by marriage. Being in Italy, at an even.
t, ing party, it fell to her lot to be handed into the
supper table by a young English nobleman, who
had a good share of the puppy in his composition.
at Thinking to quiz the lady, he said : "You are ac­
quainted with the Americans, I believe ?" "Very
well." "A monstrously vulgar people, are'ut
they ?" "Yes; but what could you expect when
t- you consider that they are descended from the
English? Had their progenitors, now, been Italians
or Spaniards, we might look for some good breed­
ing among them." The nobleman did not venture
to address Mrs. Patterson again that evening.
FATAL

. Gentlomcn have no genius for
shopping. They are not equal to it.
Nature has left their faculties imperfect
in that particular. They can write books
and makd speeches, and all that sort of
thing, but they, are not up to shopping.
It takes the ladies for that. Men go to
a store and select what they want and
buy it. ' But that is not shopping that
requires no genius for that !
Mcu pretend they do not like to go
shopping with the ladies. I wonder who
ever asked them? What lady would
have such an incumberanec on such an
occasion? Men are well enough in their
places. Young gentlemen arc convenient
to take us to concerts, and bcc us home
from Church, and bring us boquets and
music; and husbands arc useful, I suppose,
to pay the bills, &c, but for a shopping
excursion they are quite out of place.
Don't understand mo to insinuate that
I have any distinguished ability that way.
Not at all I only speak for my sex. In
fact, I acknowledge that I am regarded
by my lady acquaintances as a poor hand
at it. But my friend SallicZ. is a model
shopper. I am taking lessons, of her,
and hope to be perfect by the time I am
married. A few days since she invited
me with her.
" I wish to look at the new style silks,"
said she.
" Why, do you want a dress?" said I-
" Really," said Sallie, " if it was not
impolite, I should say you were verdant.
I don't want a dress but that's no rea­
son I should not see the material."
So Sallic and I sallied out. The first
store we entered, she asked whether the
merchant had received his spring goods.
He said he had, and enquired what she
would like ro sec.
" Show me your new style dresses,"
said she, " such as borage robes, and lawn
robes ; handsome striped and plaid silks ;
brocades aud changeable silks arc not
much worn this spring, but I'll look at
your solid colors."
The merchant soon had his counter
spread with goods. She examined aud
tossed the pieces about, making various
ugly creases in thcin, to seo whether they
would come out again by rubbing.
" What style is most worn," . inquired
Sallic.
" Well, we sell probably more ( plaids
and stripes than any other. ,
" Have you any with the chene stripe?"
" 0 yes, somo very fine," and a variety
of pieces were produced.
" Well I can't say after all, that I like
the chene stripe ; they look like the old
style, reviewed ; I prefer the plaids ; the
green is very pretty."
So Sallie held it in various lights, rub­
bing and creasing it. " Well it don't
crease much," said she, I wonder whether
it willcut." .
" No, it is boiled silk ; and we find the
plaids and stripes usually wear well.'
"Your silks are quite pretty, and you
may cut me off samples," continued Sallic.
. This the merchant was forced to do,
though with rather a bad grace, as most
of his goods was in patterns, and he
feared spoiling the piece. .
; " Will you be kind enough to give , me
samples of the solid colors?" :
These were all furnished.
" This plaid, you say, is $1 87. Is that
the lowest?" ' '.
" Yes wo can't take less."
" How many yards in the pattern ?" ,
" Fourteen." . , ,'
" I'd rather have eighteen ; perhaps . I
might conclude to have flounces. Well,
I'll take the, samples and show my moth­
cr, and then make up my mind. Have
you any .Coate's cotton ? ; Givo me a spool
No. 83, , i .i
This was handed her, and she paid five
cents, and we left. I looked at my watch.
We had been there exactly ono hour. t
" What a cheat. I can buy these spools
for four cents," said Sallic, when fairly
out, ,. " and, besides, wo , forgot their
shawls !" ;, .;'""V, V.
So wo went to another store, , .
' " Have yon Stella shawls ? .
Yes some beautiful ones just opened.
Would you see the Brocho borders or the
printed?"

Both." ' '.''''
" Any particular colors ?"
" No--I'll look at all of them," said
Sallic. ' . . :'. 7 ' '
' Different colors, qualities and patterns,
were accordingly ' produced.
"What is the price of this green cen­
ter, Brochc border ?" inquired Sallic.
" We can afford you that at nine dollars
same style sold for fifteen two months
ago. Some printed borders we can put
up at four dollars. ,
" No,' I prefer Broche but can't you
take less ?"
I saw a twinkle in the merchant's eye,
which made me think he know she was
ordy shopping
" Now," said he, " if you wont men­
tion it, I'll let you have it for six."
Sallie looked surprised. She knew
that style of article was selling at nine.
" Six dollars is that your lowest ?"
"Well, to oblige you, I'll say four."
A pause. " Then you think that four
dollars is your very lowest ?"
" Ahem ! We have a largo lot and I
want to dispose of them. I'll say two
dollars fifty cents."
Still longer pause. " Are you sure it
is a first rate piece of goods ?"
" I'll warrant it all silk and wool."
My friend was caught. Turning to me
she whispered :
" I wisli I had brought some money,"
and then addressing the merchant, she
said, " I'll call again."
I never was so glad to get out of a
Ftore before, for the clerk had gathered
round us, seeming to understand the joke.
But Sallic went home, got the money,
and insisted on my returning with her to
the store for the shawl. The trader said
he was sorry, very, but the shawl had
just been sold. And so was Sallie, too,
I thought. We went shopping no more
that afternoon.

h Carolina, which I do not
apprehend, the smothered indignation of the Free
States would be roused beyond control. It would
not be in the power of any one to restrain it. In
twenty days two hundred thousand men would be
in readiness to take vengeance on all who would
betray the Union into the bands of its enemies.—
Be assured that Ido not exaggerate the feelings of
the people. They are already sufficiently excited
at the attempt to dissolve the Union for no other
reason than that they constitutionally exercised the
most precious right conferred on them—of voting
for the person whom they considered the most wor­
thy and best qualified to fill the office of Presi­
dent. Fort Sumter, therefore, ought not, and I
presume, will not, be delivered over to South Car­
olina.

I am not, however, pleading for the Free States,
for tbey are not in danger, but for the Union and
the preservation of the Cotton States. Those who
sow the wind must expect to reap the whirlwind.
The leaders of South Carolina could not have no­
ticed that we live in an age of progress, and that
all Christendom is making rapid strides in the
march of civilization and freedom.* Iftheyhad,
they would have discovered that the announce­
ment of every victory obtained by the Hero of the
nineteenth century, Garibaldi, in favor of the op­
pressed of Italy, did not lail to electrify every
American heart with joy and gladness. "Where
liberty dwells there is my country," was the de­
claration of the illustrious Franklin. This princi­
ple is too strongly implanted in the heart and mind
ot every man in the Free States to be surrendered
because South Carolina desires it, in order to ex­
tend the area of slavery. With all Christianized
Europe, and nearly all the civilized world, opposed
to slavery, are the Southern States prepared to set
aside the" barriers which shield and protect their
institutions under the United States Government?
Would the separation oftheSouth from tbeNorth
give greater security to slavery than it has now
under the Constitution of the Union? What secu­
rity would they have for the return of runaway
slaves? I apprehend none, whilst the number of
runaways would be greatly augmented, and the
difficulties of which slaveholders complain would
be increased ten-fold. However much individuals
might condemn slavery, the free States are prepar­
ed to sustain and defend it, as guaranteed by the
Constitution.

In conclusion, I would avoid the bloody and des­
olating example ofthe Mexican States. I am, now
and forever, in favor ofthe Union, its preservation,
and the rigid maintenance of the rights and in­
terests of the States, individually and collectively.
Yours, &c., JOHN E. WOOL."
GEM. WOOL TO GEN. CASS.
[Private.)
TROY, Dec. G, 18G0.
MY DEAR GENERAL:—OId associations and lormer
friendship induced me to venture to address you a
few words on the state of the country. Mv letter
is headed private, because I am not authorized to
address you officially.
I have read with pleasure the President's Mes­
sage. South Carolina says she intends to leave the
Union. Her representatives in Congress say she
has already left the Union. It would seem that she
is neither to be conciliated nor comforted. I com­
mand the Eastern Department, which includes
South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama and
Mississippi. You know me well. I have ever been
a firm, decided, faithful and devoted friend to my
country. If I can aid the President to preserve
the Union, I hope he will command my services.
It will never do for him or you to 1 eave Washing­
ton without every star in this Union is in its place.
Therefore no time should be lost in adopting meas­
ures to defeat those who are conspiring against the
Union. Hesitancy or delay may be no less fatal to
the Union than to the President, or your own high
standing as a statesman.

It seems to me that troops should be sent to
Charleston to man the forts in that harbor. You
have eight companies at Fort Monroe, Va. Three
or four of these companies should be sent without
a moment's delay to Fort Moultrie. It will save
the Union, and the President much trouble. It is
said that to sen! at this time troops to that harbor
would produce great excitement among the people.
That is nonsense, when the people are as much ex­
cited as tbey can be, and the leaders are determin­
ed to execute their long meditated purpose of sepa­
rating the State from the Union. So long as you
command the entrance to the city of Charleston,
South Carolina cannot separate herself from the
Union. Do not leave the forts in the harbor in the
condition to induce an attempt to take possession
of them. It might easily be done at this time. If
South Carolina should take them it might, as she
anticipates, induce other States to join her.
Permit me to entreat yeu to urge the President
to send at once three or four companies of Artillery
to Fort Moultrie. The Union can be preserved,
but it requires firm, decided, prompt and energet­
ic measures on the part of the President, lie has
only to exert the power conferred on him bv the
Constitution and laws of Congress, and all will be
safe, and he will prevent a civil war, which never
fails to call forth all the baser passions of the hu­
man heart. If a separation should take place, you
may rest assured blood would flow in torrents, fol­
lowed by pestilence, famine and desolation, and
Senator Seward's irrepressible conflict will be
brought to a conclusion much sooner than he could
possibly have anticipated. Let me conjure you to
save the Union, and thereby avoid the bloody and
desolating example of the States of Mexico. A
separation of the States will bring with it the des­
olation of the Cotton States, which are unprepared
for war. Their weakness will be lound in the
number of their slaves, with but few of the essen­
tials to carry on war, whilst the Free States have
all the elements and materials for war, and to a
greater extent than any other people on the face of
the globe.

Think of these things, my dear General, and save
the country, and save the prosperous South from
pestilence, famine and desolation. Peaceable se­
cession is not to ba thought of. Even if it should
take place, in three months we would have a
bloody war on our bands.
Very truly, your friend, JOHN E. WOOL.
Hon. Lewis Cass,
Secretary of State, Washington, D. C.

let. He reports that on Monday the rebels

ture tbe forts occupied by our forces.
expedition consisted of six steamboats
about three thousand men. The steamers
were loaded with heavy rilled cannon
morturs for throwing shells. The attack
simultaneous. Ibut ineffectual The forts
fired shells, and were a?isted by the vessels
rift the Inlet.

were drowned, besides a large loss must have
been sustained from the bursting of
shells and tbe plunging of our shot, as
guns were served in a most masterly manner.

' The Latest News.
There has been lor several days an unusual dearth
of news in regard to the movements of our armies.
At last accounts General Lee's forces were m the
neighborhood of Winchester, chiefly at Bunker Hill
Our forces are said to be in excellent condition, and
their numbers largely increased.
The enemy has advanced in strong force across
the Potomac at several points and a battle has been
expected daily. Whether McClellan will attack
Gen. Lee in his present position may be doubtful.
We think the indications are, that Richmond is
still the object of the enemy, and that the attempt
will be made to move upon it from all points.
From Kentucky and the South we have nothing
very important Our telegraphic dispatches give
the latest information.
We learn that two Yankee gunboats went up
Blackwater river some days ago, when a portion of
Col. Ferebcc's Cavalry dismounted and attacked
them, killing six of those on board.
P. S. Gen. Van Dorn has obtained a victory at
Corinth. See dispatch. -
The Conservative Meet ins oa Saturday Last.
We invite attention to the proceedings of the
Conservative Meeting held in this City on Saturday
last The meeting was large and enthusiastic, and
the best spirit prevailed.
It will be seen that CoL Daniel G. Fowle was
nominated to fill the vacancy in the House of Com­
mons, occasioned by the death of Mr. Miller. With
all respect for the claims of other gentlemen, we
think the meeting has made an excellent selection.
CoL Fowle is a gentleman of fine attainments, and
will ably, and no doubt acceptably represent the
County in tke House of Commons. We do not
know whether he is to have opposition or not; but
if he should, and if the Conservatives of the Coun­
ty should turn out in force, as we feel sure they
will, he will be elected by a large majority.
The Fever at Wilmington. We deeply regret
to learn that there is no abatement of the fever in
Wilmington, though the disease appears to be sub­
mitting to treatment more readily than at first.
The promptitude of Charleston and Mobile, and oth­
er places in extending their sympathy by sending
physicians, nurses, and necessary comforts, is high­
ly commendable. It will be seen that our citizens
have taken steps to afford such relief as they can.
It is hoped that all will aid liberally.
The Journal reports during the week ending on
Friday evening last, 267 new cases and 82 deaths.
The mortality is very large, yet it is probable that
it is even larger than that obscure cases no doubt
escaping efforts to ascertain them. We trust in a
few days a marked change for the better will be
manifest
f We are indebted to Hon. Mr. Oldham, "of
Tesas, for a pamphlet copy of his able speech on
the Conscription Act
Wheat! wheat! The high prices of wheat and
flour should admonish our planters throughout the
State to sow largely of wheat for the next crop.
Let every effort be made to sow a full crop.
WoRTnv or Imitation. The State Convention of
South-Carolina at its late session adopted a resolu­
tion, providing for the public registration by a proper
officer of all the names of the officers and soldiers of
that State who have or shall fall during the war in
the service of their country, whether killed in bat­
tle or dying from wounds or disease contracted in the
service, with the company or corp3 to which they
belonged, &c. We hope our next Legislature will
cause such a rceord or memorial to be made of all
the dead of this State, with a proper notice of any
remarkable instances of daring, 4a
The Yarbkouch Will Case. This important
case was argued and decided at the last term of
Wake Superior Court, (last week) his Honor Judge
Heath presiding. It appears that Col. Yarbrough,
during his last illness, made two wills. By the
first he gave to his children his real estate, and to
his wife eight thousand dollars in cash ; and by the
second will he gave the real estate to his wife, and
the cash mentioned to his children. The first will
was made the 21st, and the last the 25th of March,
a few days before he died. The Hon. George E.
Badger and H. A. Badham, Esq., appeared for the
first will, and B. F. Moore and G. W. Haywood,
Esquires, for the last The case was very ably ar­
gued on both sides, and the. jury declared the first
will to be the true one. The real estate, (the Ho­
tel) therefore, goes -to the children, and the eight
thousand dollars to his widow.
We conclude to-day the publication of an essay on
Free Trade. We differ with the writer in many of
bis views, but it must be conceded that be has han­
dled the subject with ingenuity and ability.
CoRRECTio-In the lettes of Joseph D. Joyner,
published in our last, he was made to say, " My
regiment has been in three battles in a week, while
others have fought more" It should have read,
" while others have fought none."
The rumor brought by late telgraphic dispatches
that Gen. Phelps and Com. Porter are been cap­
tured by the Confederate gun-boat, No. 290, at the
mouth of the Mississippi is all bosh. They arrived
W New York in the steamer Roanoke a fortnight ago.
The Yankee Cavalry have certainly visited W"ar­
ronton, Va., and captured and paroled about 2,500
of our sick and wounded soldiers who were incapa­
ble of making any resistance. Is that allowable by
the cartel?
The Houston Texas Telegraph says -that Gen.
Sam. Houston was alive and in ordinary healh, liv­
ing on his farm on Cedar Point on the 3d Sep­
tember.. Jhe,Federa' bare recaptured the seven engines recently
en by our troops near Warrenton.

Two days after Lincoln issued bis emancipation
proclamation, he sent forth another of which the
following b an xtrtct:"'.. .. V
" Whereas, It baa become necessary to call into
service not only volunteers but also portions of the
militia of the States, by draft, in order to suppress
the insurrection existing in the United States ; and
disloyal persons are not adequately restrained by
the ordinary processes of the law from hindering
this measure and from giving aid and comfort in
various wajs to the insurrection. Now, therefore,
be it ordered
First That during the existing insurrection, and
as a necessary measure for suppressing the same,
all rebels and insurgents, their aiders and abettors
within the United States, and all persons discourag­
ing volunteer enlistments, resisting militia drafts,
or guilty of any disloyal practice, affording aid and
comfort to the rebels against the authority of the
United States, shall be subject to martial law, and
liable to trial and punishment by courts martial or
military commissions;
Second That the writ of habeat corpvt is sus­
pended in respect to all persons arrested, or who
are now, or hereafter, during the rebellion, Bhall be,
imprisoned in any fort, camp, arsenal, military prison
or other place of confinement, by any. military au­
thority or by the sentence of any court-martial or
military commission." j
He has thus assumed and practices without the
name, the powers and tyranny of the Military Dic­
tator puts a lock upon every man's mouth closes
the mouth of the public press exercises a censor­
ship over every man's thoughts and acts arrests
him for every act judged to bo treasonable by his
sworn pimps and spies brings him before a bloody
court of his own appointment, and cuts off his last
hope for liberty by suspending at will the writ of
habeat corpus all over the land. If the North sub­
mits to this, and we fear she is sufficiently enslaved
to do it, her days of civil liberty are numbered.
All this Lincoln does and thousands justify his acts
as a 44 military necessity.' According to his avow­
ed doctrine, there is nothing he cannot do in a state
of war as commander-in-chief, if he consider it nec­
essary to be done to save the State. This is the plea
of despotism every where and in all ages. -
Now here in the South, every man denounces all
these acts as tyrannical and devilish, and yet there
are those who would have President Davis pursue
the same course. There are not a few, who would
sanction to-morrow the assumption of the Military
Dictatorship by President Davis. They advocate
and justify the arrest and imprisonment of citizens
who have heretofore borne a good character, upon
mere suspicion they would deny their own fellow­
citizens against whom they cannot alledge a fault,
except a difference in political opinion, the right of
trial by jury or the writ of habeat corpus. They
sanction the most cruel acts upon the part of mili­
tary tyrants against subordinates and citizens they
will endorse whatever the authorities may do, how­
ever nuch against law or without law. Many of
them are par excellence State rights men, and yet
they would surrender every right claimed by the
States to the will of the President, unless it came
in direct conflict with their own personal interests.
They are for pressing every man into the war ex­
cept themselves and their particular favorites, unless
they can secure offite and position. In other words,
they are for a despotism, provided they and their
friends can be the lieutenants and subordinates of
the despot
Soldier's Claims. Many of our brave soldiers
have recently been killed in battle or have died
from wounds or disease contracted in camp. It
is likely the government was in debt to many of
them, and their wives and children may be in much
need. To such widows and other claimants, we
again suggest the easiest method of obtaining it
According to the law, we believe, the wife is the
first claimant, the children next, father next, mother
next; if he have neither wife, child, father or moth­
er, then the claim goes to the nearest of kin.
Let the soldier's widow, therefore, if he have one,
and if not the child, or father, or mother, as the
case may be, apply to any intelligent magistrate,
and make oath that the deceased soldier, naming
him, who belonged to such a company and such a
regiment, and died, or was killed at such a time
and place, and was the husband, father or son of the
witness, and that there is no nearer claimant living
than the witness. Let the magistrate then testify
on the same affidavit to the credibility of the wit­
ness. Then take the affidavit to the Clerk of your
County Court, and get the Clerk to certify, under
the County seal, that the above named magistrate is
a bona fide Justice of the Peace for said County.
Get any responsible friend to take the affidavit to
Richmond, if going, or send it to the member of Con­
gress from your district, paying the postage, Ac.,
to collect it for you from the War Department We
make this suggestion to guard poor soldiers' widows
and orphans against sending the claim to agents for
collecting such claims, who make exhorbitant char­
ges for their labor. Some charge 10 per cent for
collecting, which often deprives the needy of a good
portion of the claim.
Information. A correspondent at Cold Spring,
Carroll County, Ya., desires us to make known to
the authorities in this State, that there is a man
who calls himsel James Gurlsy, a deserter from
this State, now living on the Blue Ridge, near Pi­
per's Gap, who has a horse and wagon, and has
been hauling liquor about in that country and pas­
sing counterfeit money. Our informant says that
Gurley admits that he has a family below High
Point, and that he stabbed a man while at Camp
Mangum. He can be found near Cold Spring, Car­
roll County, Ya.
Capt. W. T. Marsh. We regret to learn that
this gallant officer received a wound in the battle of
Sharpsburg, of which he died on the 24th Septem­
ber. We saw his servant on Saturday last, who
showed us Capt M's watch, which was struck by
the bullet that caused his death. The watch is a
small gold one, and was in his over-shirt pocket on
bis left breast The ball struck the lower part of
the watch, crushed and bent it, and passed into his
tody. ..Capt M. lingered for about a week at the
house of Mr. McQuilton, two miles this side of
Shepardstown, where he was kindly nursed and
cared for. Captain M. belonged to the 2d State
Troops, having entered the service at the beginning
of the war.' He was a young man of much promise.
He was a member of the last Legislature from Beau­
fort County, and hail been reelcdted a member of
the present Legislature.
Edward Everett, of Boston, in a late speech,
falsely insists upon it that there are still in the
South many Union men who are waiting to be de­
livered by Yankee arms. Gen. Fremont, in another
speech, tells a different story. He says in his cam­
paigning in Virginia he did not find a Union man
certainly he did not see a Union woman. -

A Goon Idea. The Richmond Equirer states
that there are twenty or thirty ladies employed in
signing Confederate Treasury notes, Ac., in the
Treasury Depatment in that city. This gives a
chance to the young men to enter the army. Bring
the ladies into the business of the country the
men are needed elsewhere.

Northern News.
A friend has handed us several copies of the New
York Tribune, Timet, Herald and Pott, of recent
dates, from which we -learn that Lincoln's procla­
mation in regard to slavery b generally approved,
and that the war spirit is as rampant in the North
as ever. There may be, and there no doubt b a
strong under current in the Northern States against
Lincoln and his measures, but, so far as we can
judge by the papers before us, the people are gen­
erally sustaining him in his despotic conduct , Yet
the Tribune, in the mid6t of its fierce and wicked
assaults on the South, seems to fear that liberty b
not safe in the Northern States. In his issue of
the 4th September Greely says:
44 In times of great public peril like the present,
it seems necessary to wink at official acts of arbitrary
power which would not be endured for a moment
in a state of peace. We do not surrender our liber­
ties, but we hold them in abeyance while the Na­
tion's fate trembles in the balance. - We are living
under a regime not of Law but of Force. " In war,
the Law is silent," is the gist of a very old maxim.
Any of ns may be snapped up at a moment's notice
and immured in prison indefinitely, without other
warrant than some functionary's order. And who­
ever is must make the best of his fate, knowing that
all this is casual and transitory. In our poor judg­
ment, nine-tenths of the arbitrary arrests thus far
had far better not been made ; but we would not
deprive the Government of the power to make them
in a crisis like the present Let it be distinctly
understood, however, that each arrest will be made
the subject of rigorous and dispassionate inquiry
after Peace, and that, while no one should suffer for
his innocent mistakes in honestly endeavoring to
serve and save his country, it will go very hard with
any one who is proved to have gratified his own
malice or his lore of exercising despotic power,
withont the warrant of a public necessity.
What we mainly apprehend, however, b not that
individuals shall suffer they always do and must
suffer in a convulsion like this but that the talu­
tary popular instinct which regards with jealovty
every infringement oj constitutional tafeguardt for
Liberty may be debauched and broken down. We
fear there are too many patriots this day who, if
their hearts were laid upon, would be willing to
reward with an imperial crown the Military genius
who should speedily and utterly crush out the
Rebellion. In view of this tendency, it is in one
sense fortunate that our struggle has as yet develop­
ed no Cromwell, Napoleon, nor even an Andrew
Jackson. Corrupted as public sentiment has become
by forty years' truckling to the Slave Power, too
many might be ready to evince their gratitude to the
saviour of our Nationality by making him a present
of our Liberty."
Terrible visions, it seems, of military power and
imperial crowns are floating before even the aboli­
tionists of the North. If they are alarmed at the

concentration of all power in the hands of one man, 1
what must be the dread for the future of the
thoughtful and conservative portion of the North­
ern people. I
The Herald of the 27th August contains shock­
ing accounts of the murders and ravages committed
by the Sioux Indians on the frontiers of Minnesota.
Whole towns and settlements had been exterminat­
ed by the Indians. The most active military pre­
parations were on foot to check the incursions of the
Indians. The attack b attributed to the failure on
the part of Lincoln's government to make the an­
nual payment to the Indians in time.
These papers teem with accounts of the raising
of battalions and regiments, and statements of what
the different States and towns and counties are do­
ing in thb respect It seems to be highly probable,
judging by these accounts, and by the tone of the
leading presses of the North, that Lincoln will be
able to raise as many troops as he wants.
Capt. R. S. Tucker. This worthy and gallant
officer is now on a brief visit to his family and friends
in this City. We are indebted to him for the list
of our sick and wounded in Washington, which ap­
pears in another column. Capt T. visited Wash­
ington recently with a flag of truce to see about the
condition of our sick and wounded. He was at first
refused admission, but at length succeeded in get
ting through the lines through the interposition of
CoL Luko Lyman, of the Yankee forces. Capt T.
found our sick and wounded doing as well as could
be expected. They were cheerful, and well treated,
and the expectation is that they will be released in
a few days.
Eastern Counties.
Our information from the North-eastern Counties
beyond the Chowan and Albemarle Sounds, repre­
sents them to be in a deplorable condition. Full
one half of the negroes have been run off by the
Yankees, and every species of property is constant­
ly subject to their depredations. In the Eastern
Counties matters are no better. Every day adds to
their misery, which must be increased by the en­
forcement of the Yankee confiscation act, which will,
doubtless, soon be executed.
The course of Butler in New Orleans, and the
spirit of Yankee rule in Missouri, will be inaugurat­
ed in North-Carolina. CoL Polk, of Missiouri, has
been robbed of half a million of property, and his
family are said to be entirely dependent upon the
charities of others. The homestead of even Presi­
dent Taylor, which he bequeathed to his son, has
been confiscated, and thousands of wealthy men all
over the land hare been reduced to poverty.
Now what can our people in Eastern Carolina ex­
pect better from their enemies? 44 Gov. Stanly"
has held out to them the hope of protection to them­
selves and their property," if they will take the oath
of allegiance ; but the late proclamation of Lincoln
shows that, 60 far at least as negroes are concerned,
it b no projection whatever. The idea that only
the slaves of "rebels" are to be declared free on
the first of January next, is a cheat and a decep­
tion. Men who have shamefully violated their own
consciences and taken the oath, have found out the
deception when it was too late. We again admon­
ish our Eastern people not to trust to the hypocrisy
and false pretences of Yankees longer. Let them
remove all their movable property as soon as pos­
sible.In the mean time we beg to assure all the people
of the East, that every effort will be made for their
defence and protection during the coming winter.
We know that Gov. Yance is deeply interested in
affording every possible protection to them. Their
condition and wants will be fully laid before Presi­
dent Davis, and the government will be urged, in
the strongest terms, to afford them ample protec­
tion. What is lacking on the part of the Confeder­
ate government will be promptly afforded by Gov.
Vance, as far as ho has the power and tho means to
do so. We trust the efforts of both governments
may prove every way effective.
The rumor is again started, that in commercial
circles in Europe, it is predicted that the Southern
Confederacy will be soon recognised, and that nego­
tiations between France and Russia are in progress
to effect that object The story has 'been told too
often to be believed.
' Death or Capt. Guns. We record with deep re­
gret the death of Capt Chalmers Glenn, of Rocking­
ham, of the 13th regiment He fell in the battle of
Sharpsburg, and was buried by his comrades on the
field, his grave having been dug with their bayo­
nets. Peace to hb ashes. ' A nobler soldier sleeps
not in our soiL

This Bloody War. ''. ' .-'
Who can estimate the weight of responsibility :
which hangs upon the Bonis of those wicked and.
evil-guided men, who, by years of toil and labor,
brought upon tha country thb bloody' war X Time
can never develop nor cure the evils which already
have been inflicted by their demon-like agency.
A writer in a late Northern paper says it has al­
ready cost the North the lives or the ruin of 400,000
.persons. The debt incurred by Lincoln tnd his
party cannot be less than $2,000,000,000 already.
The demoralization of the North its recklessness
of moral principle its stark mad infidelity, b almost
universal. Repudiation and infidelity in its treaties
and contracts will mark its future history.' Its re­
formation cannot be effected in a century.
' Upon the South, the ruin b incalculable. One
hui dred thousand brave men have either died, or
their constitutions broken down, or they are maimed,
rendering them a burden to themselves or to society.
The loss in property cannot' now be estimated.
And where b the ruin to end f From tho North
there is nothing to hope from Europe we can look
for no sympathy. Nothing, perhaps, could gratify
English statesmen more than the utter ruin of both
North and South. -
A Philadelphia write, an abolitionbt of course,
alluding to Lincoln's emancipation proclamation,
says it was what was demanded both by the North
and by. Europe. He thinks it closes np all prospect
of European interference.
Our reliance must be, as we have always said,
upon the justice of our cause, the arm of Divine
Providence, and the valor of our troops.
The Yankees are violating the cartel in every way. At
Sbepherdstown 700 Yankee paroled prisoners werere-captured,
and it is said the Harper's Ferry prisoners are sent
off to fight the Indians in Minnessota.
The flax culture in Island has not been much increased
by the scarcity of cotton in Europe.
For the Standard.
Pursuant to a call of bis Honor, the Mayor of this
City, a number of citizens met at the Mayor's office,
to make arrangements for obtaining and sending
supplies, &&, to the people of Wilmington.
On motion. Captain Everard Hall was called to
.the chair, and H. S. Smith, appointed secretary.
Hon. John H. Bryan offered the following reso­
lutions, which were unanimously adopted :
Resohed, That we have learned, with the deepest
sorrow of the afflicting dispensation of Providence
by which our'iellow-citizens, of Wilmington, are
subjected to a pestilence causing great mortality
among them.
Resohed, That our fellow-citizens of Wilmington
are entitled to, and do receive, our profound sym­
pathy, and that we will endeavor, by all means in
our power, to alleviate their sufferings.
Resolved, That a committee of six be appointed
to solicit of the citizens of Raleigh and vicinity, con­
tributions of food, money, Ac., for the relief of the
citizens of Wilmington.
The following persons were appointed the com­
mittee under the last resolution : Messrs. P. F. Pcs­
cud, W. L. Pomeroy, J. J. Litchford, W. H. Jones,
Charles Dewey and 1L W. II us ted.
On motion, the meeting adjourned.
EVERARD HALL, Ch'mn.
IL S. Smith, Sec
Raleigh, Oct 4, 1862.

CONSERVATIVE MEETING IN WAKE.
A large and rcspectablo meeting of the Conserva­
tives of Wake County was held in Raleigh, on Sat­
urday the 4th instant, to nominate a candidate for
the House of Commons, to fill the vacancy occa­
sioned by the death of Henry W. Miller.
On motion of Gen. R. W. Haywood, Allen Adams,
Esq., was called to the Chair, and Messrs. Joseph
D. Hayes and William S. Mason were appointed
Secretaries.
The' Chairman having explained the object of the
meeting, on motion of Mr. Holden, a committee of
five was appointed to draft resolutions for the action
of the meeting. The Chairman appointed Messrs.
W. W. Holden, William H. Hood, Nathan Ivy, Ed­
ward ChappelL, and Stephen Stephenson. The com­
mittee having retired for a short time, returned and
reported through Mr. Holden, the following resolu­
tions :
Jitsolced, That in common with onrTellowcitizens of all
parties, we deeply deplore the death of Henry W. Miller,
one of the Cuinnoners elect from this County to theLegislature-
We will long cherish the recollection of his no­
ble qualities of mind and ueart, and of his patriotic dero­
tion to the State and to the caime of Southern indepen­
dence.Jietolctd, That we congratulate the people of the State
on the result of the late elections, by which Col. Vance
was made Gorernor and a Conservative Legislature se­
cured. We point with pride and satisfaction to the Inau­
gural speech of Gov. Vance, as embodying the sentiments
and wishes of the whole people of this State in this great
emergency; and we pledge ourselves, as heretofore, to
wage the war in defence of oar country as lung as a hostile
foot is on our soil.
Rttolved, That we, the Conservatives of the County of
Wake, are determined to maintain nnity and harmony
among ourselves, and to do our full part in preserving lib­
erty at home while our brave soldiers are contending for it
in the field ; and that, as one of tbe important results of
the late election, we confidently expect that oar State gov­
ernment will be reformed, and our sea-coast Counties pro­
tected as far as possible sgainst tbe ravages of the enetnv.
Jieeoivett, That we respectfully suggest that this meeting
vote by ballot, each Conservative present being entitled to
one vote; that a majority nf all the votes cast shall be nec­
essary to nominate a candidate ; and that we pledge our­
selves to support tbe nominee of this meeting.
After some remarks by Mr. Holden, setting forth
in a clear and forcible .manner the pnnciples of tho
Conservative party, and paying an eloquent tribute
to the memory of the late Henry W. Miller, the
resolutions were unanimously adopted.
The meeting then proceeded t ballot for a candi­
date. CoL Nathan Ivy nominated CoL Daniel G.
Fowle, and R. W. Sea well, Esq., nominated Maj.
Willie D. Jones. CoL Geo. Little and Peleg Rogers,
Esq., were appointed to superintend the election.
They reported that of the votes cast CoL Fowle bad
received 109, Maj. Jones 28, scattering 8. CoL
Fowle was then declared duly nominated, and
Messrs. W. W. Holden, W. 11. Hood, and J. J.
Litchford were appointed to inform him of hb
nomination and request his acceptance. CoL Fowle
soon after appeared, and accepted the nomination in
an impressive and eloquent speech ; after which, on
motion, the meeting adjourned.
. . ALLEN ADAMS, Chm'n.

FROM MISSISSIPPI.

CAIRO, Nov. 8.

Advices from Holly Springs to Wednes­
day state that large reinforcements from
Texas and Louisiana are pouring in. There
was no movement of rebel troops from that
place, except Villipigue's brigade to Mer­
idian.The people of Hernando are said to be
moving slaves and other property into the
interior.
The Grenada Appeal says Judge John 0.
Campbell has been appointed Assistant
Secretary of War of the Confederacy, rice
Professor Bledsoe, resigned.
The federal foroes nt Island No. 10
have again occupied the Tennessee shore,
and are now constructing a fort under the
protection of the federal gunboats.
A dispatch from Jackson, Tenn., of the
2d, Bays that news received at Grant's
headquarters yesterday from the South via
Rienzie confirms tbe reported capture of
Mobile.

Great Wfieat Show In Rochester.
State Agricultural Room?, )
Madison, July 20, 1863, £
Messrs Editors ;—lt Laving been ar*
ranged by the farmers of New York that
an exhibition of wheat, open to all parte
ot the United States and the British Prov­
inces shall be held at Rochester on the
Bth and 9th of September next, I desire,
through yonr columns, and in advance of
the next issue of my own paper, to notify
the wheat-growers of Wisconsin of said
exhibition, and to urge the advantage
which might be derived from a competi­
tion on their part.
The premiums are not so large as to be,
of themselves, a snliicient inducement,
but inasmuch as Wisconsin has really
produced some of the best wheat hitherto
grown in this country, as well as the larg­
est yield of any one State in the Union, it
seems to me very desirable that her high
high reputation for quantity should be
added to by a satisfactory demonstration
of superior quality.
But there is still another important rea­
son why our State should be represented.
Experience has shown that wheat, as well
as other grains—and, perhaps, to a greater
degree than most others—is improved by
an occasional change of seed. The pro­
posed Exhibition will afford an excellent
opportunity for exchange, and the best
possible selection ot new and approved
varieties foi trial.

The premiums and conditions of com­
petition are as follows:
For the Bst HO bushels of White Winter
Wheat $l5O 00
For the Second Beet do 75 00
For the Best 20 bushels lied Winter Whea 10*1 OU
For the Second Best do do 50 00
For the Beet 2 bushels White Winter Wheat 50 00
Fur the Second Best do do 25 00
For the Best 2 bushels Ked Winter Wheat.. AO 00
Fur the Second Best do do 20 00
For the Best 2 bushels Spring Wheat. .... 20 00
For the Second Best do do 10 00
** Competitors ter these Brizes will be required
to furuisn samples of the wheat in the ear and
with the Straw attacl ed, (say fifty ears of wheat
and straw,) also to lurnish a written statement of
the nature of the soil ou which the wheat grew,
method of cultivation, time ol sowing, quantity of
seed sown, manures (if any used,) and mode and
time of application ; also the time of ripening and
harvesting, and the yield per acre, with such other
parti ulars as may he deemed ot practical Impor­
tance ; also the name by which the variety is known
in the locality where it was grown. The Wheat
must ho one variety, pure, and unmided. The
pnze to he awarded to the actual grower of the
wheat, and the wheat which takes a prize is to be­
come the proper, y of the Society.”
The time of holding this Fair has been
fixed so as to enable farmers to purchase
seed for (ah sowing from the wheat enter
ed lor competition.
Should there be a disposition ou the
part of the farmers of this State to com­
pete, I have hut little doubt that arrange­
ments can be made with all the interme­
diate railroads for transportation of both
gra.n and exhibitors at reduced rates.—
Presuming upon such disposition, I shall,
at all events, endeavor to make such ar­
rangements on their behalf, announcing
the result of my negotiations as early as
practicable.
Notice of intent to compete, or enqui­
ries for further information as to the Ex­
hibition, may be addressed to Joseph
Harris, Rochester, N. Y.
The promise ol a great crop of good
wheat was hardly ever heller, in this
State, than to-day. Let us hope that our
farmers will avail themselves ot this op­
portunity to make the most of it.
Respectfully, J. W. Hott,
Secretary W. t*. A. S.

Marshal General.

CIRCULAR No. 47.
War Def’t Brovost Marshal Gm.’s Office, t
Washington, D. U., July 17, 1563. $
Drafted men become soldiers of the United
States by the fact ol their names having been
drawn in the dralt. The notification served ou
them by the Brovost Marshal is merely an announce­
ment of the fact, and an order for them to report
for duty at a designated time and place.
The following opinion of Hon. Wm. Whiting,
the Solicitor of the War Department is published
for the information of all concerned
“ Y\ hen a person has been drafted in pursuance
of the enrollment act of March 1563, notice of
such dralt must be Served witbir. ten days, and
thereafter by written or printed notice, to be served
on him personally, or by leaving a copy at his last
place of residence, requiring him to appear at the
reude.vous and report for duty. Any person fail­
ing to report for doty after notice beu.g left at his
last place of re-’denco, or served on him personal­
ly, without furnishing a substitute or pt ving three
hundred dollars, is pronounced by law t he a de­
serter.
“Ue may be arrested and held for tr Iby court
martial and sentenced to death.
•* If person ihange his place of re? Isace after
being dratted “Od before receiving no ice, it may
still bo served by leaving at his last piaco of resi­
dence, and if he does not appear In accordance
with such notice, or lurnish a substitute, or pay
three hundred dollars, he will be in law a deserter,
and must be treated accordingly.”
There Is no way or manner In which a person
once enrolled can escape his public duties, and
when dratted, whether present or absent, whether
he changes bis residence or absconds, the rights of
the United States against him are secured, and it
Is only by the performance of his duty to the coun­
try Chat he will escape liability to be treated as a
criminal. (Signed) JAS B- FUT,
Brovost Marshal General.

Another Outrage on Personal Lib­
erty:.—The Eiu Claire Free Press has a
touching account of a gallant ebony col­
ored individual named Brown, in that
place who some years since wooed and
won a white maiden. Since their marriage
Othello has taken to drink, and was re­
cently arrested while amusing himself by
walloping Lis fair Dksdemona with an
ox-goad. The Free Press continnes :
The parting with his <l loved and lost”
was affecting in the extreme. Before Mr.
Brown—belter known as nigger Brown—
left his domicil, his injured but forgiving
wife took him to one corner ot the room
and pressed to his lips a farewell kiss and
a bottle of whisky, as a pledge ot con­
tinued faith and fidelity ; and he, in turn,
bid her be cheerful in her affliction.
When he was about to enter the jail he
called the attention of the jailer, and, in
a most affecting manner, spoke as follows ;
“ I claim to be a citizen of the United
States, and am brought here against my
will. Therefore’on will receive me as
your prisoner.v
We learn from his keeper that, like fhe
great Oh;o martyr, he takes his confine­
ment easy, and expects soon to Lave his
course vindicated before the people. In
fact he baa already been solicited by the
Albany meeting and the Copperhead De­
mocracy ot Ohio, to allow the use of his
name in connection with Vallandigham’s,
to complete a Presidential ticket tor that
party. The longer and closer Brown is
confined, the stronger he gets ; and as it
is behved by them that popular liberty
has received a severe blow by bis incar­
ceration, there is every reason to expect
that policy as well as principle will give
the two martyrs preference, and that
*• Traitor Vallandigham and Nigger
Brown ” will be the standard bearers of
the Copperhead Democracy in 1864.

FROM THE SOUTH.
.Richmond views of Things in General
A C harleston Estimate of 1 kings in Particular.
[Special Dispatch to the Chicago Tribune.]
Washington, July 20.—The Richmond
Enquirer ot the 15th mst., has a lung edi­
torial on the military situation, urging
that the only salvation of the Southern
Cuufede- -oy is in calling out a levy en
masse, and the application of martial law
to the whole country, which is in a state
ot siege; absolute control ot ail trading,
especially in drink, as within military
lines; abolition of substitution, exemp­
tion and foreign protection, and a material
enlargement of the President’s power to
revise election of officers, make appoint­
ments, and get rid ot incompetent officers.
A proclamation by Jeff'. Davis appears,
calling out under the Confederate Conscrip­
tion Act, all white men between the ages
of 18 and 45, to serve lor three years, un­
der penalty of being punished lor deser­
tion in case of disobeying the call. They
are offered the privilege of joining the
volunteer organizations before enrolment.
The Enquirer says an official dispatch
from Charleston, received yesterday morn­
ing, states that all was quiet. The enemy
are throwing up works on the south cor­
ner of Morris Island. Two Federal iron­
ciade entered the Appomatox river, but
the river is obstructed above, and there
were hopes by the fall of the freshet, to
catch the iron-dads aground. The Charles
ton Mercury, received in Richmond on
the 16th, Las the following on the situation
there:
44 It appears to us useless to attempt to
disguise from ourselves the situation. By
whose fault we got into it, it is in vain
now to inquire. The Yankees having got­
ten possession of the southern halt of
Morris Bland, there is but one way to
save the city of Charleston, and that is
the speedy and unflinching use of the
bayonet.
“ The fight ou Morris Island is to be
now fought by engineering and cannon
merely. The advantage is with the en­
emy, With their iron-dads on the water,
and their men in occupation of the land,
it is likely to be a mere question of time.
The fall of Fort Wagner ends in the tail
ot Charleston. Fort Sumter, like Fort
Wagner, will then be assailable by both
laud aud sea, and the fate ot Fort Pulaski
will he that ot Sumter.
“ Geu. Gilmore, the commander of this
department, is the man who reduced Fort
Pulaski.
14 Charleston must be saved a Richmond
was. For six days our forces stormed the
successive batteries of the enemy and
saved Richmond. The greater part of the
soldiers who achieved these triumphs, by
the bayonet, had never before been m a
charge. These Yankees have as yet tew
or no lormidable works; they have but a
few thousand troops. It our soldiers and
officers here are not equal to the kind ot
fighting fought by the army of Virginia,
and tried by the Yankee.! against such
strong works as Fort Wagner and Seces­
sionville, then Charleston tails. This ap­
pears to us as the only course of safety,
and we may add, too, for the economy ot
lives. Other means may protract the
fighting to days and weeks, and postpone
the termination of the straggle. No oth­
er means, in our opinion, will save the
city. W’e believe it can easily be saved,
wuh promptness, energy and dash. It is
too late for engineering. Hesitation and
delay are fatal.”

His Excellency, Edward Salomon, Governor of
Wisconsin:
Mr:—Enclosed I send you a list of the
killed ami wounded in the engagement
near Beverly Ford, June 9th, 1883.
I was detained by sickness from par­
ticipating in ibis engagement and was
obliged to remain Behind in camp. It is
gratifying, however, to be able to report
that the bravery of the old 3d was again
severely tested, and they were not found
wanting.
In comparison to the battle of Chancel­
lorville, this engagement was a mere skir­
mish, yet, this regiment had vhe honor of
filling an important position, clearing the
way for our cavalry by skirmishing in
their front, and driving them from stone
walls, rifle pits and timber, and challeng­
ed the admiration of all by their coolness
aud their effective shots.
Respectfully, your obedient servant,
William Hawley,

Who Leads the Mob.—The New York
Evening Port says: In the conspiracy
now under examination in Philadelphia,in
which there has been disclosed a system­
atic attempt to run the blockade with
vessels sent from our harbor, and loaded
with goods from New York shelves, and
a’-o to famish the rebels with information
aud supplies, several letters are to be of­
fered in evidence, showing the complicity
ot New York men with the rebels in
. L hmond. The Philadelphia Press re­
ports that one of these letters is from the
man Andrews, of Virginia,who is a leader
ot the mobs which are to-day murdering
and pillaging our people. Is ibere no law
in the land that villains such as he may be
punished ?
Tuk Sbif.it of Patriotism. Both of the
sons of Edward Everett were dralted at
Boston, and are going to serve in the
ranks. Wealthy and amply able to hire
?nbstitutes, or pay the S3OO exemption,
they nevertheless propose to shoulder the
musket. One of these young men pos­
sesses talents ot the highest promise, and
but recently graduated at Cambridge, or
Oxford, England —we do not remember
which—where he Lad won distinction by
bis oratorical talent.
i=r 4 My dear hearers,” said a preach­
er, discoursing on the awlal subject ot
death, ** there's nothing that destroys so
many lives as death. Some people are
killed by accident and some in battle;
some a lost at sea, and some are devour­
ed by wild bea?ts ; but, my dear hearers,
it is a solemn trutti that nothing kills so
many as death. Aye, death has been at
work ever since sir. entered the world,
and has destroyed millions on millions of
the human family."

Telegraphic News.
FROM CHARLESTON.
The Norris Island Fight—Details of the
First and Second Day’s Bombardment
—Sumter Breached and Cummiug’s
Captured and Re-Captured. ~
Boston, July 18.—The Herald's corres­
pondent gives the following account of
the second day’s fighting on Morris Island :
On the morning ot July 4tfi, the 6th
Connecticut and 9th Maine regiments
made a fnrions attack upon the Cumming’s
Point battc-y, got possession of it, and
hoisted the American flag at daylight.—
Fort Sumter opened upon them, when a
cowardly Pennsylvania regiment deserted
them, refusing to stand by their comrades.
The other regiments held the battery until
they were badly cut up, and then aban­
doned it, and the rebels again took pos­
session ot it. These two regiments have
snown themselves heroes in this campaign.
At 10 o’clock a. x. the Monitors proceeded
to attack Cummitg’s Point battery, and at
12 o’clock, three ot the wooden gunboats
opened on the battery at long range, and
threw their 200-pound shot directly int
the works.
Fort Sumter has been throwing shells
into Morris Islani, without doing any
damage to our side.
The cannonading ceased at 4P. M. The
Monitors have been supplied with fresh
crews from the different ships.
fhe iron-clad Montauk has just arrived
from Port Royal. She is over the bar,
making, with the gunboats, fourteen ves­
sels in front of Morris Island and Sumter.
We shall recommence the attack to-mor­
row morning, vhen we are sure of si­
lencing the (Jamming's Point battery and
Fort Johnson. Everything is working
well. The ball has opened in earnest.
The Memphis lias just brought in a
rebel side-wheel steamer, loaded with cot­
ton, captured while trying to run out at
Ball’s Bay, last night.
P. S.—Oar troops will have their bat­
tery done in two days more, and then they
can shell Sumter.
New York, July 18.—Advices by the
Fulton, state that the result of Gilmore’s
operations, up to the morning of the 14th
are; He has possession ol all the batte­
ries on Morris Island, save Fort Wagner.
It is reported that our ironclads hau made
a breach on the sooth wall of Sumter.
On the 13lh. 113 wounded rebels were
brought iuto Folly Island, many of them
stating that they were forced into the reb­
el service. They art Germans, and will
be sent North. Other advices by the
Fulton re merely corroborative of the
Boston Herald reporter’s account.
NewT York, July 19.—Full details of the
operations against Charleston are pub­
lished.
During the operations, a rebel steamer
attempted to land reinforcements on Mor­
ris Island, hut was driven off and destroy,
ed by our gunboats, and the troops barely
escaped. It is reported also that the
rebel gunboat venturing too near our ves­
sels was captured.
Our loss in the capture of the Morris
Island batteries, and the attempt ca Fort
Wagner, toot—7lh Connecticut, 109, a
large number of whom are missing ; 3d
New Hampshire, 8 killed and 21 wounded;
76th Pennsylvania, 149 killed, wounded
and missing; 7lh New Hampshire, 5
wounded; 6th Connecticut, 1 killed and
11 wounded; 48th New York, 4 killed
and 23 wounded; 62d Ohio, 1 wounded ;
9ch Maine, 3 killed, 85 wounded, and 20
missing.
Vicksburg, July 15.—Special to the
Chicago Journal.—Geu. Herron’s division,
with the gunboats De Kalb. Signal and
Kenvood, left, on the 11th, tor Yazoo City.
Towards the night of the 18th, the mam
body of the troops moved np the left bank
—the gunboats a little in advance. At
1,500 yards the rebel battery opened on
the DeKalb. The tire was returned. Our
troops advanced steadily, and drove the
rebels out ot the battery and rifle-pits.
They then evacuated, retreating. Mean­
while, a small infantry force on the right
bank surprised the rebel steamer Sf. Marys
opposite the city, captured her and toe
crew. So tar, all right.
In the evening the gunboats ran above
the town. The Signal discovered aud
picked up a demijohn torpedo. It soon af­
ter exploded under the Huron DeKalb.
She was rnn ashore and made fast. The
Kenwood came up, took off the officers aud
crew an! personal property, aud she went
down stern foremost. She was one of the
oldest and best boats, and cost $200,000,
and carred 200 men and 13 guns.
A few minutes after, another torpedo
exploded at the how ot the Kenwood. No
damage vas done.
Johnson has made a stand at Jackson,
is entrenihing, and has at least 25,000
men. Slerraau’s right is on Pearl river
below, and his right above town. Both
armies art preparing for a battle. It may
occur any day, and must be very soon.
Gen. Lanman was ordered to make a
recon noisstnee on the 10th, concluded to
take Jackson on his own account, made
an assault, and was driven hack with tfie
loss ot ovc* 300 killed and wounded.—
Sherman relieved him of command, and
put him unier arrest for disobedience of
orders.
Skirmishng continues every day. At
last advices no general engagement had
taken place.

Tullahoma. Tenn., July 18.—A dispatch
from Gen. Ccok, at Winchester, says that
rebel scouts from Chattanooga represent
the general belief in that place to be that
Charleston hasfallen. Influential citizens
say that the news comes from a reliable
source. A perUct gloom prevailed among
the rebel army and the populace in con­
seaneuce.
Col. Wilder’s imanted infantry has re­
turned from a hign'y successful expedition
to Columbia and Centreville. Ibe force
consisted of the 123d Illinois, Col. Monroe,
and the 17th Indians, Col. Jordon—the
whole under comtmnd of Col. Monroe.
The expedition Las Veen out six days and
brought back nearly 600 horses and moles
and 250 negroes. Eighty head of the
stock and 212 negrojs were taken from
Gen. Polk. Several skirmishes were had
in the course of the trip, resulting in the
killing of ten gnerril&s and the capture
of fl'e commissiontd officers and fifty
privates Col. Gent rebel, was too se­
verely wounded to b brought forward.—
He was paroled aid left in a country
house. Oar loss is ane

Trash " is the South. Capt. Randolph of the
3d (colored) South Carolina Volunteers relates a
characteristic story of a prisoner of war, exempli­
fying the sublime ignorance in which the poor,
non-ilaveholding whites of the South are steeped.
Last February, when the United States troops
penetrated to Jacksonville, Fla., some Confede­
rate soldiers were captured. A motley crew they
were, whose picturesque variety of ruggedness
bore here and there some indications of aim at
military style, but nothing of what could be called
uniform, lwo men claimed exemption from cap­
ture as being civilians. One of the two owned to
having been impressed into the Confederate
Army, but alleged that he had got his discharge
and wss a civilian. " How long were you a sol­
dier ? " asked Captain Randolph. " Three years,"
replied the prisoner. "The CoLfederato Army
has been three years in the field, eh P" asked the
Captain. " No," answered the cracker, " but 1
was in the State of Florida service part of the
lime."

Gentlemen of the Senate and House of Ilepre
tentative:.
Obedient to the mandate of the people, I
appear before you to-day to assume the du­
ties of Chief Magistatc of the State of Ohio.
I am not ignorant of the magnitude and im­
portance of the position, nor unmindful of
my own want of experience and ability to
so administer it, as to satisfy the expecta-
tions of tlio people who have chosen me.
Most gladly would I have seen its honors
and duties imposed upon some abler citizen
of the State; and it is with no ordinary de­
gree of diflldence that I assume to-day its
labors and responsibilities. I can only as­
sure vou,gentlemcn,and those you represent.
that I bring to this position a fixed deter­
mination to discharge its duties, to the best
of mv ability, in a spirit of unyielding
laitniuiness anu integrity to tne state,
and impartiality and justice to the peo­
ple.. There is a significance in the recent ex­
pression of the' popular will that relieves us
all from many of the embarrassment that
usually attend such events. It heralds no
mere party triumph it is no individual suc­
cess. No mere partisan effort could have
achieved such a victory; no man in the
State is worthy of. or could have received,
so sublime au "ovation. It is a spontaneous
declaration of the intense loyalty of our
people to their government, and bearing it
with the stern commandment that every
energy of their State, and every exertion of
its rulers, snail do given to tne restoration
of that government to its original unity and
power. It not only relieves us of all mere
partisan trammels and alllnities, but it com­
mands us that, for the time being, these shall
be laid aside, until the great purpose is ac­
complished of restoring our country to a
position in which partisan contests may be
indulged without involving our nationality;
and party victories be won without their
possible results giving encouragement to
rebels in arms against the supremacy of the
Constitution and laws of tlie land.. In that
spirit I accept tlio late declaration of our
common constituency; and humbly thank
them that, in this particular, they have
made my path easy and straight before
me.
While this national obligation is laid up­
, on us, it does not relieve us from the fur­
ther duty of guarding the local interests,
and promoting the prosperity of our own
State. This duty, to a large extent, dc­
.volves upon the legislative body. I fully
share in the confidence of the people who
have called you from your respective avo­
cations in fife, and committed to you, for
the time being, the honor, the credit, and
the prosperity of the State. In all that I
can, and properly may do, it will give me
great pleasure to co-operate with you in
the accomplishment of this great purpose,
r The annual message of my worthy pre­
decessor, with the accompanying docu­
ments, presents you, in a concise and intel­
ligible manner, the condition of our State
affairs. His recommendations are worthy
of, and will undoubtedly receive, your care­
ful consideration. His arduous labors have
AAnl-lhiifofl In Tin fitiiflll Vlporpp. tn rhA
gratifying results presented to you; ana u
is a pleasing reflection that the people of i
the State will be able to follow him into his
present retirement from executive duties,
with the grateful plaudit of "well done
good and faithful servant." It will be an
abiding pleasure to me, if, at the end of my
own brief service, I shall be able to attain
alike his Usefulness and his reward.
It is not less gratifying than honorable to
the State that we have T)een able to pass
through tho third year of an expensive and
sanguinary war, in tho full performance of
all our amies 10 me iauonai viovernmeni,
without impairing, in any manner, the
prosperity of the State, or oppressing our
peoplo by burthensome or excessive taxa­
tion.The flnoncial condition of the State is
highly satisfactory. The currency is In a!
soq lid condition. The agricultural, indus­
trial and commercial interests of the State
were never more prosperous. The State has
been protected, with a single exception,
from invasion, and the desolating ravages
of war have not spread themselves within
our limits. At the same time the great in­
stitutions of education and benevolence,
wltich constitute a material clemeat of our
pride and strength, have not been en­
. croached upon or impaired. Our schools
and colleges our seminaries of learning
our arts and sciences! our noble institutions

.

TO THE SUPPORTERS OF TIE 00 VFRN11ENT:

We have read with surprise, but not
without Indignation, the Proclamation of
the President Of the 8th of July, 1864.
The supporters of the Administration are
responsible to the country for its conduct:
ana it is their right and duty to check the
encroachments of the Executive on the au­
thority of Congress, and to require it to
confine itself to its proper sphere.
It is impossible to pass in silence this
Proclamation without neglecting that duty;
and, having taken as much responsibility
as any others in supporting th Adminis­
tration, we are not disposed to fail in the
other duty of asserting the rights of Con­
gress.The President did not sign the bill "to
guarantee to certain States, whose Govern­
ments have been usurped, a republican form
of government" passed by the supporters
of his Administration in both Houses ol
Congress after mature deliberation.
The bill did not therefore become a lavx
and it is therefore nothing.
The Proclamation is neither an approval
nor a veto of the bill; it is therefore a docu­
ment unknown to the laws and Constitution
of the United States.
So far as It contains an apology for not
signing the bill, It is a political manifesto
against the friends of the Government.
So- far as it proposes to execute the bill,
which is not a law, it is a grave Executive
usurpation.
It Is fitting that the facts necessary to en­
able the friends of the Administration to
appreciate the apology and the usurpation
be spread before them.
The Proclamation says:
"And whereas the said bill was presented
to the President of the United States for
his approval less than one hour before the
eiiie die adjournment of said session, and
was not signed by him"
If that be accurate, still this bill was pre­
sented with other bills which were signed.
Within that hour, the time for the sine rfi'e
adjournment was three times postponed by
the votes of both Houses; and the least in­
timation of a desire for more time by the
President to consider this bill would have
secured a further postponement.
Yet the committee sent to ascertain if the
President had any further communication
for the House of llepresentatives reported
that he had none; and the friends of the
bill, who had anxiously waited on him to
ascertain its fate, had already been inform­
ed that the President had resolved not to
sign it.
The time of presentation, therefore, had
nothing to do with his failure to approve it.
The bill had been discussed and consider
ed for more than a month in the House of
llepresentatives, which it passed on the 4th
of May; it was reported to the Senate on
the 27th of May without material amend­
ment, and passed the Senate absolutely as
it came from the House on the 2d of July.
Ignorance of iA contents is out of the
question.
Indeed, at his request, a draft of a bill
substantially the same in all material points,
and identical in tbe points objected to by the
Proclamation, had been Aid before him for
his consideration In the winter of 18C2-C3.
There is, therefore, ho re:Mn to suppose
the provisions of the bill took the President
by surprise.
On the contrary, we have reason to bcl Icve
them to have been so well known that this
method of preventing the bill from be­
coming a law without the constitutional
responsibility of a veto, had been resolved
on long before the bill passed the Senate.
; We are Informed by a gentleman entitled
to entire confidence, that before the 22d of
June in New Orleans it was stated by
a member of Gen. Banks's staff, in tho
presence of otlier gentlemen in otnclal
position, that Senator Doolittle had written
a letter to the department that tha House
Iteconstruetionbill would be staved off in
the Senate to a period too late in the session
to require the President to veto it in erder
to defeat it. and that Mr.1 Lincoln would
retain the bill, If necessary, and thereby
defeat it. "'. ' - . 1 '
.The experience of Senator Wade, in his
various efforts to get the bill considered in
the Senate, was quite in accordance with
that plan: and the fate of the bill was
accurately predicted :' by letters received
from New Orleans before it had passed the
Senates ." " ". ' "' '" -'
. Had the Proclamation stormed there, it
would have been only one other defeat of
the will of the people by an Executive
perversion of the Constitution
! But it goes further. The President says:
"And whereas the said bill contains, arnone
other things, a pian ior restoring tne Mates
in reDeiuon to tneir proper practical rela­
tion in the Union, which plan expresses the
sense of Congress upou that subject, and
which plan it is now thought fit to lay be­
fore the people for their consideration"
By what authority of the Constitution?
In what forms? The result to be declared
by whom? , With what effect when ascer­
.tained?, ,
Is it to be a law by the approval of the
people without the approval of Congress at
tbe wm 01 tne rresmenir
t Will the President on. his opinion of the
popular approval, execute it as a law?
Or is this merely a device to avoid: the
serious responsibility of defeating a law on
which so many loyal hearts reposed lor se­
curity? .
But the reasons now assigned for not ap­
proving the bill are full of ominous slguiil­
cance. ,.. .;i . . ,r. . '. ,
; The President proceeds: . ,.
"Vow. therefore. I. Abraham Lincoln.
President of the United States, do proclaim,
declare ana niaKO Known, mat, wnue 1 am
fns I was In December last, when bv nroc-
laraatlon I propounded a plan for restora­
tion) unprepared, by a formal approval of
this bill, to be inflexibly committed to auy
single plan of restoration"
i That Is to My, the President is resolved
that the pepple shall hot ly law take, any se­
curities from the rebel- States against a re­
newftl of thB Trellion,' (before restoring
their power to govern ub. . . , ,.
His wisdom and prudence are to be our
sunlctint guarantees! 3 1 s : i :.:; :
Jle lurther Bays: . ----
"Ami. while I am aTso' nnnrebared to 6.
chirt that tbe FreeStote Constitutions and
Governments already adopted and installed
id'Arkansas and Louisiana shall be set aside
and held for naught, thereby repelling and
discouraging the loyal ,cltlzens. who nave
let itp tne same as w mrmer enurs - v . .
Thatte'tosav.the President perBists in
recognizing those shadows bf GorernmenU
in Arkansas and Louisiana, whlctrCongress

formally declared should not be recognized
whose Kenresentatlves and Senators were
repelled by formal votes of both Houses of
congress w men it was tieciareu iorniany
should have no electoral vote for President
and Vice President. .
They are the mere creatures of his will.
They cannot live a day without his support.
They are mere oligarchies, imposed on the
people by military orders under the forms
of election, at which generals, provost­
marshals, soldiers and camp-followers were
the chief actors, assisted by a handful of
resident citizens, and urged on to prema­
ture action by private letters from the
President.
, In neither Louisiana nor Arkansas, bo­
fore Banks's defeat, did the United States
control half the territory or half the popu­
lation. In Louisiana, Gen. Bank's procla­
mation candidly declared : "The fundamen­
tal law of the State is martial lawJ"
On that foundation of freedom, he erect­
ed what the President calls "the freeConsti­
tutlon and Government of Louisiana."
But of this State, whose fundamental law
was martial law, only sixteen parishes out
of forty-eight parishes were neld by the
United States; and in five of the sixteen we
held only our camps.
The eleven parishes we substantially held
had 233,185 inhabitants; the residue of the
State not held by us, 675,617.
At the farce called an election, the officers
of Gen. Banks returned that 11,346 ballots
were cast, but whether any or by whom the
people of the United States have no legal
assurance: but it is probable that 4,000 were
cast by soldiers or employees of the United
States military or municipal, but noneaccording-
to any law, State or National, and
7,000 ballots represent the State of Louisi­
ana. '
Such Is the free Constitution and Govern­
ment of Louisiana; and like it is that of Ar­
kansas. Nothing but the failure of a mili­
tary expedition deprived us of alike one in
the swamps of Florida; and before the
Presidential election, like ones may be or­
ganized in every rebel State where the Uni­
ted States have a camp.
The President, by preventing this bill
from becoming a law, holds the electoral
votes of the rebel States at tho dictation of
his personal ambition.
! If those votes turn the balance In his fa­
vor, is it to be supposed that his competitor,
defeated by such means, will acquiesce?
It the rebel majority assert their suprem­
acy in those States, and send votes which
elect an enemy of the Government, will we
not repel his claims?
Ana is not that civil war for the Presi­
dency, Inaugurated by the votes of rebel
States?
Seriously impressed with these dangers,
Congress, ":? proper constitutional authority"
formally declared that there are no State
Governments in the rebel States, and pro­
vided for their erection at the proper tune;
and both the Senate and the House of l'ep­
resentatlve3 rejected the Senators and Rep­
resentatives chosen under authority of what
the President calls the Free Constitution
and Government of Arkansas.
The President's Proclamation "holds for
nawjht" this judgment, and discards the au­
thority of the Supreme Court, and strides
headlong toward the anarchy his Proc­
lamation of the 8th of December Inaug­
urated. -
If electors for President be allowed to be
chosen in either of those States, a sinister
light will be cast on the motives which in­
duced the President to "hold for naught"
the will of Congress rather than his Gov­
ernment in Louisiana and Arkansas,
That judgment of Congress which the
President defies was the exercise of an au­
thority exclusively vested In Congress by
the Constitution to determine what is the
established Government in a State, and in
its own nature and by the highest judicial
authority binding on all other departments
of the Government.
The Supreme Court has formally declared
that under tho 4th section of the IVth arti­
cle of the Constitution, requiring the United
States to guarantee to every State a repub­
lican form of government, "it rests with
Congress to dctide what (-fovernment is the
established one in a State;" and "teien Sen­
ators and Representatives of a State are ad­
mitted into the councils of the Union, the
authority ot the.Government wuler which they
are appointed, as well as its republican char­
acter, is recognized by the proper constitutional
authority, and its decision is binding on event
other department of the Government, and could
not be questioned in a judicial ti ibunal. It
is true that the contest in this case did not
last long enough to bring the matter to this
issue; and, as no Senators or Itepre; ita­
tlves were elected under the authoiityof
the Government of which Mr. Dorr was the
head, Congress was not called upon to de­
cide the controversy. Yet tho right to de
clde is placed iier." '
Even the President's proclamation of the
8th of December, formally declares that
'Whether members sent to Congress from
any State shall be admitted to sents, consti­
tutionally rests exclusively with the tcsj
pective Houses, and not to any extent with
the Executive." : '
And that is not the less true because
wholly inconsistent with tha President's
assumption In that proclamation of a right
to institute ana recognize istate uovern­
ments in the rebel States, nor because the
President is unable ta percelvo that his
recognition is a nullity If it be not con
, elusive on Coneress.
' . Under the Constitution, the right to Sen­
ators and Representatives is inseparable
from a state Government. "!. .
If there be a State Government, the right
Is absolute. ' - - :
If there be no State Government, there
can be no senators or ltepresentatives cho­
sen. ': " !.-'. -i!'.
The two Houses of Congress are express­
ly declared to be the solo ludges of their
own members.'
: 1 When, therefore, Senators and Repre­
sentatives are admitted, the State Govern­
ment, under whose authority they were
chosen, is conclusively established: when
they are rejected, its existence Is as con
clusively rejected anrt denied; and to this
Judgment the President is bound to sub­
mit. .' : . - N'.-; :. - ' : ,.,! - -
The President proceeds to express his
unwillingness "to declare a constitutional
competency in Congress to abolish slavery
in States" as another reason for not signing
the bill. , - , 1 : , . t
But the bill nowhere proposes to abolish
Slavery in States. .
The bill did provide that all slaves in the
rebel States should manumitted.
' But as the President had already signed
three, bills manumitting several classes of
slaves trt States, ft Is not conceived possible
that he entertained any scruples touching
that provision of the bill respecting which
helssilent.' 't 1 u -
! He had already himself assumed !a right
by proclamation to, free much the larger
number of slaves in the rebel States, under
the authority given him by Congress to use
military power to suppress the Rebellion;
and it is qnlte Inconceivable that the Pres­
ident 'should think Congress could vest In
htm a discretion it 'could not1 exercise it­
:8elf."' -11 ''' 1 1 ; '''' : ' ' ! 1 ;-
It ia the more unintelligible from the fact
that except' in respect , to a small part of
Virginia and Louisiana, the bill covered
lonly what the proclamation covered--added
1 a Congressional title and Judicial remedies
by law to the disputed title under the proc
lamation, and perfected the work the pres­

But when 'oe describes himself, In splteof
